explanation:
- __linux__: controls the outer #ifndef; determines whether the entire sysctl-based blocks are compiled at all. If defined, large portions become absent and some code may be unreachable/removed.  
- HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME: governs inclusion of the sysctlbyname() branch. Required to know whether that if-block exists in the compiled translation unit.  
- HAVE_SYSCTL: governs inclusion of the sysctl(mib,…) branch. Required to know whether that block is present.  
- HAS_DECL_CTL_HW and HAS_DECL_HW_NCPU: these two macros appear in the same #if as HAVE_SYSCTL; their definitions determine whether the CTL_HW/HW_NCPU-based sysctl branch is compiled.  
- sysctlbyname and sysctl: need to know whether these identifiers are ordinary functions, macros, or mapped/defined away by the platform headers (they could be defined as macros or inline wrappers that affect compilation/flow). Knowing their presence/definitions helps determine whether the calls are real calls (runtime-dependent) or if preprocessing makes the call sites unreachable.  
These symbols together let an analyzer decide which source fragments are present after preprocessing and therefore whether any compiled statements or branches in the function are unreachable (MISRA: no unreachable code).
